Title: the convention conundrum

Howard: T-minus 60 seconds.
T Minus 45 seconds.
T-minus 30 seconds.
15 seconds.
Five, four, three, two, one.
Nope.
It’s been ten minutes. We’re running out of time.
Great.
Damn.
Really?
I can’t believe we’re not going.
Not the same Hulk. Ferrigno, Bana, Norton and Ruffalo.
I already found a guy online who’s willing to sell.
Sheldon, just come with us. You’re not gonna make your own convention.
Oh, and I thought our days of pretending to be with women who don’t exist were over.
And that’s where Darth Vader’s gonna pour soy sauce on your head.
What do you mean?
Why would someone want to make clothes out of your skin?
Why do you think I told him to come to your place?
I can text the guy and tell him we changed our minds.
Okay. We’re officially not going to Comic-Con.
Do what?
No need. I’m breaking rules all the time.
Last night. Drank my Pepto straight out of the bottle.
Yeah. What about it?
He just parked. He’s on his way up.
Oh, no. I’d be an astronaut and a bad boy, how will women keep their pants on?
Okay, you guys are such babies. I’ll handle this. If he thinks we’re not home, he’ll go away.
I lied about the Pepto, I always use the little cup.
Oh, God, I could really use exactly two tablespoons of Pepto right now.
Raj: Oh, it all comes down to this.
Oh, I have to go to the bathroom so bad.
And I told you I get diaper rash.
Anyone in?
Uh, what number in line are you?
Oh, they only have Thursday and Sunday passes left.
So that’s it? Everything’s sold out?
We would have been the angry green belles of the masquerade ball.
Hey, since Sheldon’s not going to Comic-Con, maybe we could find a cool trio to dress up as.
How are you gonna get James Earl Jones?
Does he sound like a criminal?
You know, did he say things like, youse guys, or, listen here, see?
I’m just saying, we don’t know who this guy is. What if he wants to steal our money or our kidneys, or make a suit outof our skins?
I don’t know. Maybe ’cause dark doesn’t show the stains?

Okay, so, I’m on a Comic-Con message board, and there’s a post from a guy where he says he got caught using someone else’s badge, and Sheldon was right, he did get charged with petty theft. Guys, if I go to jail dressed as the Human Torch, that might send the wrong message.
Do it.
That’s ’cause we’re the good guys.
You know I struggle with Batman.
Okay, I’ll be a badass, but only if you pinky-swear to be one, too.
What about that little cup they give you?
Are you impressed by that?
Yeah, me, too.
It is. I feel alive.
Maybe slapped with a fine.
Uh, maybe it’ll come up when I apply for citizenship. Oh, crap, what if it comes up when I apply for citizenship?
He’s gonna be here any second, what should we do?
I thought you were a badass.
Leonard: Oh, I’ve got butterflies.
Hey. We’re about to buy tickets for Comic-Con.
They sell out incredibly fast, but as long as one of us gets in, we can buy passes…
Well, this is it, this is it. This is it.
Not yet.
I did it, I did it, I’m in the queue.
Uh, fifteen…
…thousand two hundred and eleven.
Oh, Thursday’s gone. Just Sunday left.
Sunday’s gone.
Yeah.
Sheldon, just buy scalped tickets with us.
Do what you want. We’re getting scalped tickets.
The same way I know that the people in the TV set can’t see me.
Did you tell them that you’re holding your convention at a Marie Callender’s, and that every panellist gets a free slice of pie?
Look, even your friend Wil Wheaton thinks this is a waste of time.
Sheldon, buddy, I just don’t think this is going to come together for you.
Good luck.
Mmm, what if we go as The Fantastic Four, and just tell people that the Invisible Girl is standing there with us.
Does that step include chloroform and a roll of duct tape?
Sheldon, I don’t care if you get scalped tickets with us or not, but please don’t be creepy and go stalking this poor guy. You’re gonna get in trouble.
Yes. He, he’s late because he’s on his way here from 1940.
Well, now you’re making me wonder if we should have met him at a neutral location.
Maybe this isn’t a good idea.
Hold on. We always do this.
Chicken out. We’re, we’re so afraid of getting into trouble that we never do anything wrong.
Even Batman breaks the rules.
I say, this one time, instead of wimping out, let’s be badasses.
Howard, you in on this?
Name one.
A little.
Good. This is exciting.
Yeah. What if we do get caught, who cares? So we get banned from Comic-Con.
I wonder if we’d have to disclose something like this when we apply for grants.
Sheldon: Don’t get soft on me, Hofstadter. I will slap those glasses right off your face.
Good Lord, this is not the time for flirting, keep it in your pants.
Every year. I told you, wear a diaper.
It’s live. Go, go, go, go, go.
No.
Do not stop refreshing your screens.
Yay! And they say firefighters are the real heroes.
Oh, Sunday’s the worst. Everybody’s leaving, most of the good panels are over, and the only T-shirts they have left are small and XXXXL.
Not Sunday, I love Sunday.
It’s okay. You know, there, there’s always WonderCon in Anaheim, you know? That, that’s just as good. Excuse me.
I can’t believe we wasted all that time on our Hulk costumes.
Gentlemen, I have the solution to our Comic-Con problem. We don’t need them. I’m starting my own convention.

I told you. Buying scalped tickets is against the rules. If you get caught, you get banned from Comic-Con for life. Life, Leonard. You’re gonna feel pretty silly when we’re 80 years old, and you have to drive me down there and then wait in the car for three days.
How do you know this isn’t a sting operation set up by the Comic-Con police?
You know, there was a time when Comic-Con didn’t exist at all until one lone dreamer with a unique vision made it happen. And you mark my words, I’m gonna rip that guy off.
I didn’t even get to that part.
Not true. Wil thinks this is a great idea. He was just concerned that he wasn’t a big enough celebrity to headline such an amazing event. Also, that’s the same day that he shampoos his beard.
You don’t know that. I still have plenty of solid leads on this list.
No, wait. I need you to call Stan Lee, Leonard Nimoy and Bill Nye the Science Guy, ’cause, legally, I’m not allowed to. Oh, and, also, Carrie Fisher, you know, ’cause I hear he can be pretty nuts.
Gentlemen, I am one step away from securing a huge guest for my convention.
I don’t think that will be necessary for Mr. James Earl Jones. You heard me. The voice of Darth Vader, the Lion King’s dad, and FYI, the guy who says, This is CNN. Which also sounds like Darth Vader.

Simple. Earlier today, he tweeted that he’s looking forward to going to his favourite sushi restaurant for dinner. I googled an interview from four years ago which was conducted in his favourite sushi restaurant. That’s where he’ll be, and that’s where I’m going, and…

You’re the ones who are going to get in trouble. You’re buying non-transferable tickets. And from a stranger, no less. Not only can you get banned from Comic-Con, if caught, you could be charged with petty theft. You think about that while I’m warning James Earl Jones about the danger of posting his location on Twitter. He got lucky this time. There are some weirdoes out there. (To the Imperial March theme) Bom, bom, bom, bom, badum, bom, badum. Bom, bom, bom, bom, badum, bom, badum. Bom, bom, badala, baba, badalum, bom, badala, bom, bom, forgot my keys, bom, bom, bom, bom, badum, bom, badum…
Thank you. My friend Leonard said if I bothered you while you were eating, you’d think I was a creepy stalker.
He is, Mr. Earl Jones, he is.
Me, too. But he wasn’t, was he?
So messed up.
Is it true, as a child, you were a stutterer and were functionally mute for eight years?
Oh. Is it true they used scuba gear to create the sound of Darth Vader breathing?
Oh. Is it true that you were pre-med in college and you almost became a doctor?
Oh, James, I could listen to your stories all night.
Hey, Los Angeles. I’m on a Ferris Wheel with Darth Vader. And he’s nicer than you think.
In the jungle, the mighty jungle, the lion sleeps tonight…
Bring it home, Mufasa. Eee, eee, eee, eee, eee, um, um-a-weh.
I don’t understand what we’re doing.
Whose house is this?
Okay. But I think it could have ended with the karaoke.
Oh. How much does it cost to get them off my lap?
Oh, right. Well, my friends and I couldn’t get into Comic-Con this year, and I was trying to start my own convention, and I was going to ask if you would be a panelist.
Really?
Ay-yi-yi.
I’m sorry, who’s Angie Dickinson?
Penny: What’s going on?
Oh.
This is a whole lot of weird before coffee.
Yeah, this is not gonna be enough coffee.
To be cool? Yeah.
Oh, guys, this is really sad. And in a different way than it was twenty minutes ago.
What? You were all going as the Hulk?
And we’re back to the first kind of sad.
I can’t believe Leonard is spending hundreds of dollars on scalped tickets.
Yeah, but those tickets only get him into Comic-Con. That dress gets me into anywhere I want.
Yes, like a museum, but anything else.
Oh, all right, if we’re gonna be fancy, I should probably put on clean underwear.
No, we’re gonna stop at Target on the way.
I can’t believe we thought this would makes us feel grown up.
Well, there’s a bar in the lobby.
So, afternoon tea was a bust.
Let me ask you a question, when did you guys start feeling grown up? ‘Cause I am not sure I do.
Okay, so I’m an adult, and the other day I saw an old man slip and fall down, and I laughed. I mean, I laughed hard. Like, like, out loud. If he was conscious, he would’ve heard me.
I know. One of the tennis balls came off his walker and bounced right off his head. I mean, I, I almost wet myself. I guess you had to be there.
Okay, sex is not what makes you a grown-up.
Really? Is that how you talk to your mother?
I mean, really, what’s so great about being grown up?
I’m serious. Who wants to do all that stuff? Have insurance, pay mortgages, leave one of those little notes when you hit a parked car.
Oh, come on, it wasn’t me. Anyone could have knocked your mirror off, or whatever happened.
Sheldon (on phone): Yes, I’m starting my own comic book convention, and I thought that your client, Robert Downey Jr., would be perfect to appear on our first panel. Oh, well, now, why are you saying no? You haven’t even asked him yet. You know, excuse me, but I sat through Iron Man 2. I believe he owes me two hours of his time. They hung up on me.
Amy: Last week, you spent that on a little dress.
Why can’t they do something sensible like Sheldon and start their own comic book convention? Also, who wants to throw me out that window?
Oh. You mean like a museum?
Ooh, afternoon tea, how sophisticated of us.
There sure are a lot of little kids here.
Well, last time I got dressed up and had tea was when I was five. Just me, my teddy bear, Raggedy Ann and my hamster.
It was. Till my hamster ate all her babies. It got less cute really fast.
Aw. Drinking in the afternoon, just like her mommy.
On the bright side, every six-year-old there was jealous of my tiara. Not gonna lie, it felt good.
I think I have you both beat. Imagine trying to feel like a grown-up when you’ve never even been with a man.
I told you it was Penny.
Maybe the guys are right. I mean, we spent the whole night trying to be mature, and it was kind of boring. I’m sure they’re having more fun than we are.
Bernadette: Those tickets were pretty expensive. I had to give Howie an advance on his allowance. Now he’s never gonna put his toys away.
Well, while they’re acting like teenagers, we could do something grown-up.
Oh, I know. There’s a nice hotel not far from here where they do afternoon tea.
La-dee-da, look who has clean underwear.
I can’t believe the waiter thought I was your daughter.
I could go for a drink.
Honestly, I thought when I got married I would, but I still kind of feel like I’m pretending. It doesn’t help that most of my clothes come from Gap Kids.
Yeah. Or you’d be the oldest one here.
Well, for starters, we’d be splitting this check three ways.
Howard (on phone): Okay, great. Bye. Our friendly neighbourhood scalper says he’s running late.
James Earl Jones: Let me guess. You like Star Wars. You know, I’ve been in other movies. But you don’t care about those, do you? I have one thing to say to people like you. I like Star Wars, too. Care to join me?
Well, your friend Leonard sounds like a real weenie.
James: You know, when I first read the script for Empire Strikes Back and Darth Vader told Luke he was his father, I thought for sure he was lying.
He was not. How messed up was that?
What do you say let’s go have some fun? My wife’s in New York, and I got a Lion King residual cheque burning a hole in my pocket.
Carrie Fisher. And she’s a little crazy, so get ready to run. (Rings doorbell)
Ah, Sheldon, this is the perfect end to a perfect night.
What were you trying to ask me at the strip club?
Why don’t you and your friends come to Comic-Con with me?
Of course. And San Diego is right across the border from my favorite city on Earth, Tijuana, where I’m taking you every night.

So, Beau Bridges is on my shoulders, and Jeff Bridges is on Marlon Brando’s shoulders, and remember, we do not have permission to be in the pool… hey, Sheldon, wake up. And Angie Dickinson is about to sic the dogs on us, and I go under the water and Marlon goes under the water, and the water raises about two feet and sloshes all over her patio, and the dogs freak out and run like hell, and then we run like hell. Oh, boy, that was a lot of fun.
